title: Roger Federer sets 2020 schedule as Andy Murray casts doubts over Tokyo doubles
text:
Roger Federer discussed his schedule (Picture: TPN/Getty Images)

Roger Federer intends to compete at both the French Open and the Olympic Games in 2020, ending fears he will withdraw from the clay-court Grand Slam in order to give himself extra rest ahead of a hectic summer schedule.

Federer, 38, returned to Roland Garros for the first time in four years earlier this season, losing to eventual champion Rafael Nadal in the semi-finals, and he plans to return to the French capital again next year.

It will come as welcome news for French Open organisers, who must have been fearing the worst after Federer announced his intentions to cram Wimbledon, the Olympic Games and the US Open into a jam-packed summer of tennis.

Roger Federer will return to Paris (Picture: WireImage)

Federer has made no secret of the emphasis he places on rest and smart scheduling at this stage in his glittering career, but the French Open will not be a casualty of his decision to head to Tokyo.

‘I will play the French Open and I probably won’t play much before that,’ Federer told CNN.

‘Because I will need some time away from it. I will need some time with the family, we need vacation, we need a break.

‘Especially if I’m playing the Olympics and all that. So I’ll probably play the French, Halle, Wimbledon, the Olympics, maybe Cincinnati and then the US Open.’

Federer competed in Masters 1000 events in Madrid and Rome in order to tune up for Roland Garros in 2019, but it seems unlikely he will do the same next season.

Winning a first Olympics singles gold will be no straightforward task for the 20-time Grand Slam champion, with world No. 1 Novak Djokovic – who tested conditions in Tokyo at the Japan Open, a tournament he won, a matter of weeks ago – making no secret of his desire to do the same, with former winners Rafael Nadal and Andy Murray both set to be in the field.

Murray, who will target a third successive singles gold, may not, however, team up with his brother Jamie in Japan.

Murray cast doubt over his Olympics chances (Picture: AFP via Getty)

Doubles specialist Jamie has struck up a partnership with their compatriot Neal Skupski, which has begun to take decent shape after a slow start.

However, he has played with his brother Andy at the past three Olympic Games, though the pair have only won one match at the three tournaments combined.

And Andy, who takes on Uruguay’s Pablo Cuevas in Antwerp later on Thursday, suggested they won’t team up together in Toyko, while he won’t be willing to offer his services to Great Britain captain Leon Smith for every doubles match at the Davis Cup in Madrid next month.

‘I don’t think it’s a done deal that we will play together,’ said the older sibling, who on Thursday faces Pablo Cuevas in the European Open second round.

‘He’s been doing well with Neal and also if I played a match for example like I did with Alex de Minaur (their recent three-set marathon in China) where I’m at right now there’s no chance I’m playing doubles after that.

‘I would be useless. I was so tired at the end of that match. If I played a quick singles match and if I had a chance to eat and rest and recover then I’d want to play, but it will depend on the situation. I won’t be playing singles and doubles every day of the Davis Cup. Right now I’m not in the right shape to be doing that.’
description: Roger Federer will compete at the French Open in 2020 but Andy Murray cast doubt over his Olympics doubles participation.
